caseTitle: GHANA LOTTO OPERATORS ASSOCIATION v NATIONAL LOTTERY AUTHOR2
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana was asked to determine whether the National Lotto Act, 2006 (Act 722) violated Articles 33(5), 35(1), and 36(2)(b) of the 1992 Constitution. The plaintiffs, private lotto operators, challenged the Act's monopoly granted to the National Lottery Authority, arguing it infringed on their economic freedoms and private sector rights. The Court held that Article 33(5) does not import unenumerated rights like a right to engage in gambling, and that Article 35(1) is not violated as sovereignty remains with the people. Regarding Article 36(2)(b), the Court found the Directive Principles non-justiciable, emphasizing they are guiding principles for governance, not enforceable rights, thus upholding Act 722.
verdict: The Supreme Court ruled that Act 722 does not violate Articles 33(5), 35(1), or 36(2)(b) of the 1992 Constitution.
citations: Ghana Lotto Operators Association v National Lottery Authority [2008] GHSC 3
rationaleHighlights: Article 33(5) does not allow for the importation of unenumerated rights such as a right to operate lotteries.
Article 35(1) affirms popular sovereignty but does not prohibit state monopolies.
Article 36(2)(b) is part of the Directive Principles, which are not justiciable.
The Court emphasized that Directive Principles guide policy but are not enforceable in court.
Gambling is a regulated activity; economic freedom does not include unregulated entry into such sectors.
The absence of an explicit justiciability clause in Chapter 6 does not render it enforceable.
The State may take measures to regulate economic activities in the public interest.
Private initiative is encouraged but not constitutionally guaranteed in all sectors.
